courseTitle: Africana Intellectual Thought and Economic Development
courseDescription: This course examines Africana philosophical and theoretical thought as it pertains to issues of race, labor and production.  Through an examination of the social and economic legacy of slavery and colonialism, this course investigates how systems of exploitation have influenced the underdevelopment of Africa, the Caribbean and North America in its contribution to Western Capitalism.

courseTitle: Introduction to Critical Race and Media Studies
courseDescription: In this course, students examine how media culture - both historic and contemporary - contribute to the intersectional production of race in the United States. A guiding question will be: How do media and popular culture - as texts, practices, industries, and sites of identity formation and pleasure - construct race? Although students will theorize the politics of representation, they will also work to situate texts within a larger historic, political, and discursive context in order to assess the type of cultural work they perform.

Ability to conduct historical research to situate media texts within their larger context.
Understanding of digital media platforms and their role in the dissemination of racial narratives.

courseTitle: Biomedical Applications of Low Temperature Plasmas
courseDescription: This course is cross listed between ECE and Biology. It is intended for senior undergraduate students and first year graduate students. The course contents are multidisciplinary, combining materials from engineering and the biological sciences. The course covers an introduction to the fundamentals of non-equilibrium plasmas, low temperature plasma sources, and cell biology. This is followed by a detailed discussion of the interaction of low temperature plasma with biological cells, both prokaryotes and eukaryotes. Potential applications in medicine such as wound healing, blood coagulation, sterilization, and the killing of various types of cancer cells will be covered.

courseDescription: The principles of fluid and solid mechanics will be applied to a variety of plant and animal systems to understand how organisms deal with the immediate physical world and its accompanying constraints.  A diverse range of topics will be covered, including aerial flight in insects, wind resistance in trees, jet propulsion in squid, flow within blood vessels, forces on intertidal organisms, viscoelasticity in biological materials, and energy storage during terrestrial movement.

Knowledge of a wide range of plant and animal systems
Ability to apply mechanical principles to biological scenarios
Understanding of viscoelasticity in biological materials
Proficiency in digital tools for research and data analysis
Knowledge of the principles of energy storage during terrestrial movement
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to explain complex biological mechanics concepts
Ability to communicate research findings effectively
Ability to work in a team to conduct research and solve problems
Ability to present complex information in an understandable manner
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to analyze biological systems and understand their mechanical principles

Ability to critically analyze experimental data and draw conclusions
Understanding of how organisms deal with physical constraints
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Ability to manage and organize research projects
Ability to lead a team in research and problem-solving tasks
Ability to plan and execute experiments efficiently
Ability to manage time and resources effectively

courseTitle: Introduction to Mathematical Modeling in Physiology
courseDescription: This course introduces model development and model formulation with differential equations in physiology. The physiological focus will be on cellular physiology, particularly ion channel dynamics and homeostasis.

courseTitle: Seminar on the Modern Community College: Foundations, Philosophy, and Vision
courseDescription: A critical examination of the future of the community college, considering the current strengths and weaknesses within the higher education community. Ultimately, the course strives to prepare students to understand, assess, and contribute to the betterment of community college education. Students develop and articulate thoughts, ideas, and opinions on how to re-imagine the community college in order to improve institutional performance and to more effectively serve all students.

courseDescription: Course covers the overview of renewable energy sources; fundamentals of biofuels; biomass and types of biomass (e.g., woody biomass, forest residues, agricultural residues, energy crops); composition of lignocelluloses (cellulose, hemicellulose, and lignin); biomass conversion technologies; thermochemical, supercritical water, and biochemical conversion processes; types of biofuels from biomass; liquid fuels (bioethanol, bio-oil, biocrude, and hydrocarbons); gaseous fuels (synthesis gas, hydrogen, biodiesel); solid fuels (biochar, torrefied biomass); biodiesel from vegetable oils, algae to biofuels; value-added processing of biofuel residues; economic and environmental assessments; policies and future R&D.

courseDescription: This course focuses on building students’ listening competence and communicative fluency to a level sufficient to handle most everyday, academic, and professional encounters. In this course, students will move from listening to conversations, interviews, radio programs, or podcasts to more complex documentaries, movies, and lectures. Students will develop their discussion and conversation skills for social and academic purposes, both in and out of class.

courseDescription: This course develops multilingual and/or international undergraduate students’ foundational writing skills, emphasizing the writing process. Students learn to match writing to audience and purpose, write in a variety of academic genres, and incorporate source material into their work to be able to transfer acquired skills into discipline-specific writing. Students will learn to recognize and avoid plagiarism by developing a personal voice while also appreciating the importance of the author’s ideas and credibility. Problems with sentence structure, lexical grammar, and diction are addressed individually.   This is a non-credit course; students cannot use this course for academic credit toward a degree program.   Undergraduate Monarch English Transition (MET) Program Exit Criteria: Earn a grade point average of 2.5 in academic courses and grades of C or higher and 85% attendance or higher in the MET courses.

courseDescription: This course presents the fundamental principals and practical applications of modern electrochemical methods of analysis. Detailed descriptions and demonstrations of modern electrochemical research instrumentation will be provided.  Students will obtain hands-on experience with this instrumentation by performing a required chemical determination using an electroanalytical method, and by undertaking a special analytical project.  Research applications of other electroanalytical techniques and instrumentation, in addition to those actually used by the students in this course, will be discussed and/or demonstrated.

courseDescription: A study of the various theories that have emerged since the early twentieth century about the form, history, and cultural significance of narrative as a specific discursive mode. courseDescription: This is a writing intensive course designed with writing assignments that examine various cultural contexts that enable students to understand cultural content, style, audience and organization. The main objective of the course is increased awareness of and sensitivity to appropriate word choice, and syntax in the language.  Students will engage in writing for different cultural audiences and in varied contexts such as literary, artistic and media expressions around the world. Special emphasis is placed on the methodology of close reading as students hone the analytics skills and vocabulary necessary to interpret idioms, regionalism, cultural expressions and overall intercultural skills observed in various genres and cultures. Students will analyze compelling global issues and the diverse cultural perspectives that inform them.

courseTitle: Advanced Qualitative Research in Adapted Physical Education
courseDescription: Qualitative research seeks to make sense of, or interpret, the meaning of social phenomena in the natural setting, filtering through the multiple lens of race, social class, ethnicity, language, gender, and ability/disability. The aims of this course are twofold: (1) to highlight the contribution of qualitative inquiry to our understanding of the theory, research, and practice in adapted physical education, and (2) to provide basic skills and understanding necessary for doctoral students in adapted physical education to interpret and conduct qualitative research.

courseDescription: This course introduces the science behind some of Earth's natural phenomena that can, and often do, result in major loss of life or catastrophic damage to property. courseTitle: Learning and Development Across Historical and Contemporary Educational Environments
courseDescription: This course explores foundational ideas of democratic education in light of contemporary understandings of how children and youth construct knowledge. While focusing on the contexts and conditions of contemporary education, it traces the roots of educational theory and philosophy from the formation of the common school to the policy reforms of the 21st century. This understanding is coupled with the major theories of children's learning and development as well as all aspects of their physical, social, emotional, and intellectual development from birth through adolescence. The course requires that students learn the concepts and terminology associated with each theory and be able to use them in analyzing, interpreting, promoting, and evaluating children's growth and learning in the classroom.

courseTitle: Curriculum Development Principles and Practices in Elementary Schools
courseDescription: This course will engage students in the on-going debates about the development and shaping of curricula with an emphasis on how these forces play out in elementary schools. courseDescription: Struggles for human rights and social justice often find their most evocative expression in creative works from around the world. In this course, students will work toward an understanding of different cultural perspectives that inform global concepts of human rights. The course will focus on literary texts, film, testimonies, visual art, and other cultural forms of bearing witness. Students will also consider the fundamental value of these artistic expressions as both spaces of empathy and agents of change in society. Overall, students will consider how these narratives, embedded within, and coded by, sociopolitical contexts, contribute to today’s language of human rights and its application in struggles for social justice.
Technical and Digital Skills: Proficiency in digital research tools and techniques To source and analyze diverse cultural texts, films, testimonies, and visual art from around the world
Understanding of digital communication platforms To engage in active discussions and share ideas about global human rights issues
Competency in using multimedia presentation tools To present and interpret artistic expressions and their role in social justice
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Cross-cultural communication and understanding To effectively interpret and discuss cultural perspectives from around the world
Active listening and empathy To appreciate the value of artistic expressions in conveying struggles for human rights and social justice
Effective written and oral communication To articulate complex ideas about human rights, social justice, and their representation in art
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical thinking and analysis To dissect and understand the sociopolitical contexts embedded within cultural narratives
Problem-solving To address and dissect complex global issues of human rights and social justice
Interpretation of cultural and social symbols To decode the language of human rights as represented in different cultural forms
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management To organize and present research findings effectively
Leadership and teamwork To lead and participate in group discussions and collaborative projects
Time management To efficiently manage study and research time, and meet project deadlines
